title: technology
description:
Here: Facet that contains keywords (concepts) to describe technological aspects of artworks.
More broadly: The general application of science and related disciplines, typically to commercial or industrial objectives, often with the implication of mechanical, electronic, or computerized components.

title: MAC
description: Family of personal computers designed, manufactured, and sold by Apple Inc.
alternative_titles: Macintosh, Apple Mac, MacInTosh, Mac Computers, Macintosh Computer, Apple Macintosh

title: C++
description: General-purpose programming language.

title: CGI/Perl
description: Interpreted programming language first released in 1987.
alternative_titles: Practical Extraction and Reporting Language, Perl/CGI, perl

title: CSS
description: Declarative language for styling web pages.

title: Java
description: Object-oriented programming language.

title: Linux
description: Family of Unix-like operating systems that use the Linux kernel and are open source.

title: PHP
description: Scripting language focused on web development.
alternative_titles: Hypertext Preprocessor, Personal Home Page, PHP programming language, PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor, PHP Hypertext Preprocessor, php

title: Softimage
description: 3D computer graphics and animation programme.
alternative_titles: Softimage|XSI, Softimage XSI, XSI, Autodesk Softimage

title: Virtual Reality Markup Language (VRML)
description: File format for representing 3D interactive vector graphics.
alternative_titles: vermal, .wrl, .wrz, Virtual Reality Modeling Language, VRML

title: Extensible Markup Language (XML)
description: A standard, based on SGML, for the mark-up of electronic documents. It is designed to aid the exchange of data via the World Wide Web, and allows users to customize tags.

title: loudspeakers
description: Electroacoustic devices that convert an electrical signal into sound waves that are audible at a distance from the devices.
alternative_titles: loud speaker, loudspeaker, speaker, speakers, loud-speakers, loud-speaker, loud speakers

title: virtual retinal display (VRD)
description: Display technology that draws a raster display directly onto the retina of the eye.
alternative_titles: retinal projector, retinal scan display, RSD, VRD, RP

title: aesthetics
description:
Here: Facet that contains keywords (concepts) to describe the aesthetic qualities of artworks.
More broadly: Appreciation or criticism of the beautiful. The term refers to a branch of Western philosophy concerned primarily with the fine arts, although it may also be used in the context of the appreciation of natural beauty. Stems from the Greek aisthesis (meaning "perception").

title: displays
description: Output device for presentation of information in visual form.

title: interfaces
description: The boundry in which information is passed, usually between the system and its environment. It can be used to link the computer with peripherals or between the computer and a human user.
alternative_titles: interface, UI, user interface, user interfaces

title: genres
description:
Here: Facet that encompasses various genres to describe works of media art.
More broadly: Categories of art that are characterized by form or content.
alternative_titles: art genres, art genre, artistic genre, artistic genres, Genre, Genres

title: genetic art
description: Art involving DNA. Genetic Art has many subcategories, e.g. transgenic art, and is itself a subcategory of bioart.

title: head-mounted display (HMD)
description: Device used in virtual reality systems.
alternative_titles: head-mounted display, head-mounted displays, HMD, Head Mounted Display

title: Cave automatic virtual environment (CAVE)
description: Immersive virtual reality environment where projectors are directed to between three and six of the walls of a room-sized cube.

title: interactive installations
description: Interactive art installations directly engage viewers by positioning them as a physical part of the artwork. These types of works tend to be playful, eye catching, and inspirational.

title: virtual reality (VR)
description: Computer-simulated environment simulating physical presence in real or imagined worlds.

title: subjects
description:
Here: Facet containing topics and themes to characterize the content of artworks.
More broadly: In the visual arts, oral works, music, performing arts, and literature, the topics, themes, or other visual, oral, or written content of the work. It includes what the work is of or about.

title: Binocular Omni-Orientation Monitor (BOOM)
description: A head-coupled stereoscopic display device. Screens and optical system are housed in a box that is attached to a multi-link arm.

title: projectors
description: Devices for projecting an image upon a surface by means of the transmission of light through a transparent slide or film or the reflection of light from an opaque object.

title: inflatable structures
description: Structure supported by pressurization of the habitable space.

title: computer monitors
description: Electronic visual display for computers.
alternative_titles: computer monitor, computer screen, computer screens, display, displays, visual display unit

title: projection screens
description: A white, vertical, flat surface on which images are projected, made of reflective material. Generally used for motion picture, video, or photographic slide projection.

title: active shutter 3D systems
description: Technique of displaying stereoscopic 3D images.
alternative_titles: shutter glasses, shutter-glasses, alternate frame sequencing, alternate image, alternating field, eclipse method, field sequential, active shutter 3D system

title: mirrors (as non-electronic displays)
description: Objects with a highly polished surface, designed to reflect images clearly. The surface is typically smooth, flat, or sometimes slightly curved, made of polished metal in ancient and medieval times, but later usually of glass with a reflective coating on one side.

title: data gloves
description: Input device for human–computer interaction.
alternative_titles: data glove, datagloves, dataglove, cyber gloves, cyber glove, cyberglove, cybergloves

title: theremins
description: Electronic instruments played by the performer's hand moving back and forth at different distances from an antenna rising vertically from the instrument; the pitch of the single tone produced varies with the distance of the hand from the antenna.
alternative_titles: theremin, aetherophones, aetherphon, etherphone, etherphones, termenvoks, termenvox, thereminvox, ætherphone, ætherphones, thereminophone, thereminophones

title: camera recordings
description: Captured data or translated information on a recording format.

title: joysticks
description: Devices consisting of a vertically mounted shaft that can be pushed in any direction; used for generating signals that can cause the cursor or some other symbol to be moved rapidly about on a display screen.

title: mice (input device)
description: Small, button-operated computer devices that are moved around on a flat desktop or graphics tablet to control the movement of the cursor on the monitor.
alternative_titles: computer mice, mouse (input device), mouses (input devices), computer mouse, computer mouses

title: virtual balance
description: Interface for intuitive navigation through complex, three-dimensional virtual spaces.

title: breathing sensors
description: Device to measure breathing. It can be used as intuitive biofeedback based interaction system.

title: positiontrackers
description: Tracking a (moving) object with an apparatus or measuring device.

title: eye scanners
description: Devices to perform iris or retinal scans, or to track eye movement.
alternative_titles: eye scanner, eyetracking, eye tracking, Eye-Tracking Technology, Eye Tracking Technology

title: software interfaces
description: The languages, codes and messages that programs use to communicate with each other and to the hardware.
alternative_titles: software interface, programming interfaces, programming interface, interfaces (software), interface (software)

title: touch screens
description: A computer interface that behaves as both an input and output device. The surface of the monitor screen is overlaid with sensors of various types that allow the user to trigger software tasks.
alternative_titles: touch screen, touchscreen, touchscreens, touch sensitive screens, touch sensitive screen

title: step sensors
description: Sensor devices that notice steps, either just to count steps, or to find movement patterns, or to trigger a certain event with each step.

title: Antiquity
description: Belonging to the period or manner of ancient Greece or Rome. More specifically, referring to those aspects of classical art, particularly the representation of the human figure in ancient sculpture and also the use of ornament in ancient art, when they are used as models of perfection in other periods.

title: breathing
description: Process that moves air in and out of the lungs.

title: machines
description: Devices for applying mechanical power, often for the purpose of replacing or assisting manual labor.

title: movement
description: Act of changing the body's (or a body part's) position.

title: scientific images
description: Images used in science; also images produced within a scientific context using specialized methods, techniques, and instruments.

title: biological sensors
description: Probe which tests for biological molecules.

title: DNA
description: Refers to any of the various double stranded nucleic acids found in chromosomes of higher organisms which store and transfer genetic information.
alternative_titles: deoxyribonucleic acid, deoxyribose nucleic acid, D.N.A., thymonucleic acid, DNA spiral

title: databases
description: Structured sets of data held in computer storage, especially those that incorporate software to make them accessible in a variety of ways. A database is used to store, query, and retrieve information, typically comprising a logical collection of interrelated information that is managed as a unit, stored in machine-readable form, and organized and structured as records that are presented in a standardized format in order to allow rapid search and retrieval by a computer.
alternative_titles: database, data base, data bases, databank, data banks, data bank, data banks, digital database, digital databases, DB, db

title: dynamical systems
description: The use of any given dynamical system (e.g. mathematical or physical) for aesthetic purposes.
alternative_titles: dynamic system, dynamical system, dynamic systems

title: evolution
description: Refers to the gradual development of living organisms over successive generations, from lower to higher forms, especially as articulated in Darwinian theory or in alternatives to or modifications of Darwinian theory.

title: genetics
description: Biological science which deals with the phenomena of heredity and the variation between progenitors and offspring.

title: geology
description: Science that deals with the physical history of the earth, the rocks of which it is composed, and the physical changes which it has undergone and is undergoing.

title: historical sites
description: Parcels of land with historic significance due to historic events, architectural, engineering or archaeological activities, etc.
alternative_titles: historical site, historic sites, historic site, sites (history), site (history), heritage site, heritage place, heritage places, historic place, historic places

title: illusionary
description: Based on the distortion of the senses or perception of reality.

title: communication
description: Conveying awareness, knowledge, or information to others.

title: complexity
description: Study of complexity in regard to complex systems. Within media theory it is often applied to study social media.

title: bodies (animal components)
description: The complete physical forms of humans and other animals. Includes the outer appearance and constitution, as well as internal features, such as organs.

title: mathematics
description: Science of numbers, magnitudes, quantities expressed symbolically, and forms and figures, including their interrelationships and the operations performed on them.

title: artificial life
description: Artificial life is a field of study wherein researchers examine systems related to natural life, its processes, and its evolution, through the use of simulations with computer models, robotics, and biochemistry.
alternative_titles: Alife, A-Life, artificial life form, synthetic life, sythetic life form

title: landscapes (environments)
description: Broadly used to describe portions of the earth's surface that share common repeating characteristics that can be comprehended at a glance. Landscapes are more than scenery or political units; they are systems of natural and cultural contexts.

title: myths
description: Individual stories derived from a mythology; distinguished from historical accounts in that they are considered by current scholars to lack a determinable basis of fact or natural explanation; typically concerning a being, hero, deity, or event and explains some practice, rite, or phenomenon of nature.

title: Nature
description: Refers to the concept of the physical world, including the forces at work in it and the nonhuman life inhabiting it, perceived by human beings as separate and independent from themselves, their activities, and civilization.

title: panoramas
description: Refers generally to pictorial representations with very broad horizontal ranges of view. The term is also used specifically for photographs that show a wide view produced by a panoramic camera or by joining photographs together.

title: poetry
description: Literary and oral genre rooted in the compressed and cogent imaginative awareness or associations of experiences, ideas, or emotional responses and arranged under an organized criterion of meaning, conscious and unconscious expression, symbolism, formal or informal pattern, sound, and rhythm. The genre encompasses narrative, dramatic, satiric, didactic, erotic, and personal forms.

title: robots
description: Machines capable of automatically carrying out a complex series of movements, especially one that is programmable.

title: senses
description: The five faculties by which stimuli from outside or inside the body are received and felt.

title: sound installations
description: Interdisciplinary art installations that incorporate sound into physical environments.
alternative_titles: sound installation, environmental sound installations, environmental sound installation, sound environments, sound environment, installations (sound), installation (sound), sound-installations, sound-installation

title: games
description: Forms of competitive play, usually involving an element of strategy, especially to interfere with an opponent's play; may or may not require physical skill.

title: speech recognition
description: Automatic conversion of spoken language into text.
alternative_titles: Speech Recognition, automatic speech recognition, ASR, computer speech recognition

title: theater
description: Genre of performing arts concerning theatrical or dramatic entertainment, often reserved for works intended for stage presentations.

title: weather
description: State of the atmosphere with respect to such factors as wind, temperature, cloudiness, moisture, and pressure.

title: cities
description: Distinctions among villages, towns, and cities are relative and vary according to their individual regional contexts. Generally, cities designate large or important communities with population, status, and internal complexity greater than most towns in the region.
alternative_titles: city, communities (urban), community (urban), urban communities, urban community

title: dreams
description: Successions of images, thoughts, or emotions passing through the mind during sleep.

title: telematic art
description: Artworks using computer-mediated telecommunications networks.

title: gesture
description: Movement and positioning of limbs, hands, or body as a means of intentional expression.

title: earth
description: The world as considered the dwelling place of of living creatures, the surface of the planet; contrasted with sky, heaven, hell, etc.
alternative_titles: Planet Earth, Earth, World, world, Gaia

title: speech
description: The act of expressing or describing thoughts, feelings, or perceptions by the articulation of words.

title: animals
description: Any living organisms, including human beings; may be real or fictional, including mythical or legendary creatures.
alternative_titles: animal, Animalia, the animal kingdom, Animal Kingdom

title: humans
description: Members of the species to which all modern human beings belong. Homo sapiens is one of several species grouped into the genus Homo, but it is the only one that is not extinct.
alternative_titles: human, Homo Sapiens, homosapiens, man (Homo sapiens species), human beings, human being, human beings, mankind, peoplekind

title: algorithms
description: Sets of logical procedures for solving problems in a finite number of steps.

title: microscopy
description: Generally, the use of or investigation with a microscope.

title: motion pictures (visual works)
description: Works presented in the form of a series of pictures carried on photographic film or video tape, presented to the eye in such rapid succession as to give the illusion of natural movement.
alternative_titles: motion picture (visual work), film, films, movies, movie, moving pictures, moving picture, moving-pictures, moving-picture, cinematic work, flick

title: archaeology
description: Scientific study of the material remains of past human life and activities, including human artifacts from the very earliest stone tools to the man-made objects that are buried or thrown away in the present day. Archaeological investigations are a principal source of knowledge of prehistoric, ancient, and extinct cultures.

title: outer space
description: The physical universe beyond the earth's atmosphere, consisting of near vacuum with small amounts of gas and dust. Usage often excludes celestial objects, but includes the expanse in which celestial objects are situated.

title: house walls
description: Vertical architectural members used to define and divide spaces. In English, there is no distinctive term for an external wall and the internal sides of a room, but this is not universal. Many languages distinguish between the two.
alternative_titles: house wall, interior walls, exterior walls, interior wall, exterior wall

title: code
description: Method to represent information for various purposes (storage, transmission, protection against unauthorized access etc.).
alternative_titles: codes, data encoding, encoding, data code, data codes

title: narrative
description: Based on account of a series of related events or experiences. An emphasis on storytelling.
alternative_titles: narrative, narration, narrative work, work of narration

title: gender
description: The state or condition associated with male, female, neutral, or other social or cultural distinctions and differences, rather than strictly biological ones.

title: documentation
description: The process or function of gathering and recording information, especially to record facts or characteristics or to establish evidence or testimony. Here, particularly with regard to scientific documentation.

title: net art
description: Works made with and existing in the context of networked systems, meant to be accessed via network protocols. This term is not used to refer to reproductions of art made in other media that is represented on Web sites or online media. 'Web art' is considered a separate concept, as net art may use protocols other than the World Wide Web. Some argue that net art is independent of technology, and is defined only as work that uses systems or social situations as the medium, but the majority of these works exist in the context of computer networking systems.

title: robotic art
description: Any artwork that employs some form of robotic or automated technology.

title: plants (as non-electronic interfaces)
description: Multicellular eukaryotic life forms characterized by photosynthesis, in which chemical energy is produced from water, minerals, and carbon dioxide with the aid of pigments and the radiant energy of the Sun. However, also included in the kingdom are plants that do not produce their food by photosynthesis, but rather are parasitic and live off of other living plants. Other plants are saprophytic, obtaining their food from dead organic matter. Plants have cells that contain cellulose in their walls and are therefore to some extent rigid. There is also an absence of organs of locomotion, resulting in a more or less stationary existence as well as no sensory and nervous systems. There are over 300,000 living species of plants.
alternative_titles: plant, plantæ, green plants, green plant

title: microphones
description: Devices that convert acoustical sound waves into corresponding variations in electrical current that are then amplified, transmitted, or recorded.

title: SGI Onyx
description: Graphics system manufactured by Silicon Graphics.

title: transgenic art
description: Transgenic art is a new art form based on the use of genetic engineering techniques to transfer synthetic genes to an organism or to transfer natural genetic material from one species into another, to create unique living beings. It is a subcategory of Genetic Art and involves actual DNA sequences or lifeforms produced through genetic engineering.

title: mixed reality
description: Merging of real and virtual worlds to produce new environments.

title: scanners
description: Digitizers that derive data from the scanning of opaque or transparent images.

title: psyche
description: Totality of human consciousness.

title: magic (occult science)
description: Study and practice of ritual activities intended to control or influence human or natural events through the invocation of external and impersonal mystical forces beyond the ordinary human sphere; typical ritual activities include the manipulation of special objects and the recitation of spells.

title: emotion
description: Refers to a complex phenomena and quality of consciousness, featuring the synthesis or combination of subjective experiences and perceptions, expressive physiological and psychological behaviors, and the excitation or stimulation of the nervous system. Among psychological studies, the concept is associated with ideas on personality formation, rational and irrational thinking, and cognitive motivation.

title: combinatorics
description: Combinatorics is an area of mathematics primarily concerned with counting, both as a means and an end in obtaining results, and certain properties of finite structures.

title: intermediality
description: A generic term for phenomena at the point of intersection between different media, or crossing their borders, or for their interconnection, typically in the context of digital media.

title: keyboards
description: Sets of levers or keys actuating the sounding mechanism of keyboard instruments.

title: perspective
description: Refers to any graphic method concerned with conveying an impression of depth, usually on a two-dimensional surface, by means of geometric projection using one or more vanishing points, foreshortening, and/or atmospheric effects.

title: cyborgs
description: Cybernetic organisms, often depicted in science fiction works as humans with machine parts.

title: urban space
description: Areas within city limits or closely linked to them by common use of public utilities or services.
alternative_titles: urban spaces, urban area, urban areas

title: politics
description: The art or science of government or governing, especially the governing of a political entity, such as a nation, and the administration and control of its internal and external affairs.

title: globes
description: Representations of the Earth, heavens, or another planet in the form of a ball.

title: brainwave sensors /brain-computer-interfaces
description: Connection between brain and computer.
alternative_titles: brainwave sensor, brain-computer interface, brain computer interface, mind-machine interface, direct neural interface, synthetic telepathy interface, brain–machine interface, BCI

title: augmented reality (AR)
description: The use of digital technology to overlay visual real-life representations, usually provided through video, with computer-generated data.

title: digital graphics
description: Digital graphics combine text and images to produce a graphic product.

title: digital animation
description: Process of creating animated images by using computer-assisted or computer-generated techniques. It includes limited animation where only a part of the figure is animated, and sophisticated animation, where computers supply in-between drawings based on a limited number of hand-drawn images and digitized figures that can appear to move or rotate convincingly through space.

title: surveillance
description: The function of watching or guarding people, activities, or situations, usually having a connotation of spying on a suspected person or a prisoner, or observing in order to provide supervision for direction or control.

title: endoscopes
description: Instrument used to examine the interior of a hollow organ or cavity of the body.

title: cameras
description: Lightproof boxes fitted with a lens through the aperture of which the image of an object is recorded on light-sensitive material such as film, or transformed into electrical impulses for direct transmission or for video recording.

title: retina scanners
description: Device for the biometric technique that scans unique patterns on a person's retina blood vessels

title: webcams
description: Video cameras that are connected to or are integral to a computer so that its output may be viewed online.
alternative_titles: webcam, web camera, Web camera, Web cam, Webcam

title: database art
description: Database art is a form of digital art that uses the digital archive as both a source of artistic imagination and a form of critical inquiry.

title: nanoart
description: Nanoart is a novel art discipline related to science and technology. It depicts natural or synthetic structures with features sized at the nanometer scale, which are observed by electron or scanning probe microscopy techniques in scientific laboratories.

title: assembled
description: Consisting of multiple parts.

title: sublime
description: The conception or expression of awe-inspiring grandeur in a work of art.

title: installation-based
description: Artworks that use their exhibition space as part of their design and demand a viewer's active engagement.
alternative_titles: installations, installation, installation works, installation-work, installation art

title: contextual
description: Highlighting the interaction between artists and social situations, and the formal, social, and ideological conditions of the artist's production, in contrast to the functions of traditional art.

title: multi-user
description: Allowing for interaction of more than one user at a time with an artwork.

title: panopticons
description: Buildings, as prisons, hospitals, or libraries, so arranged that all parts of the interior are visible from a single point.

title: panoramatic
description: Revealing a wide, all-encompassing view of a particular subject. Pictorial representations with very broad horizontal ranges of view.

title: acoustic
description: Based on the properties of sound, especially the sound properties of built environments, materials, and sound devices.
alternative_titles: acoustical properties, acoustical property, acoustic properties, acoustic property, acoustic oscillation, acoustic vibration

title: representation
description: A manner of expression by the artist in which the subject matter is presented so that the observer is reminded of actual visible forms. However, the subject represented may or may not exist in the visible world. For example, representations may include presentations of subject matter that are invisible to the eye, such as emotions or imaginary events, as if they are visible.

title: violence
description: The use of physical force so as to kill, injure, damage, or abuse.

title: production
description: Act of creating goods or services.

title: meme
description: A meme is an idea, behavior, or style that spreads by means of imitation from person to person within a culture and often carries symbolic meaning representing a particular phenomenon or theme. In popular language, a meme may refer to an Internet meme, typically an image, that is remixed, copied, and circulated in a shared cultural experience online.

title: utopias
description: Places of ideal perfection, especially with regard to laws, government, and social conditions.

title: interculturalism
description: Support for cross-cultural dialogue and challenging self-segregation tendencies within cultures.

title: Postmodernism
description: Refers to the style and period of art and architecture that developed in the 1960s and after, when there was a clear challenge to the dominance of Modernism. Generally speaking, it advocated a pluralistic approach to the arts and it stated that Modernism had failed because of a lack of a coded language of meaning to the viewer.

title: post-structuralism
description: Critical theory similar to structuralism in its critique of historicism, meaning, and post-Renaissance rational philosophy, but differing by its rejection of structural linguistics as a theoretical base, emphasizing fragmentation instead, with a belief that there can be no historical progress nor any cumulative progress in knowledge.

title: semiotics
description: Theory and study of signs and symbols dealing especially with their function in languages, including syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.

title: democracies
description: Political entities have a government in which people either rule themselves or elect representatives to rule in their interests. Elections, to be democratic, must be held regularly, be secret, and provide a choice of candidates; the elected assembly must also be free to legislate and criticize government policy.

title: folklore
description: The body of traditional beliefs, legends, customs, music, arts, material culture, etc. that is shared by a culture or group of people.

title: communities
description: A community is a body of people who live in the same place, usually sharing a common cultural or ethnic identity; may also include a body of people who do not necessarily live in the same place, but share common interests or backgrounds, and typically meet or communicate regarding these interests.

title: legislation
description: Declarations of laws, regulations, fund allocations, international treaties, etc., having the force of authority by virtue of their passing or enactment by an official organ of a state or other governing body.
alternative_titles: law, laws, legal system, legal systems, legislative act, piece of legislation

title: institutions
description: Formally structured organizations, establishments, or associations created for the promotion of a specific benevolent public or private objective, usually a religious, charitable, or educational objective, such as a church, school, college, hospital, asylum, reformatory, mission, or the like.

title: popular culture
description: The dance, literature, music, theater, cinema, television, language, fashion, and other cultural indicators intended for or appreciated by the mainstream public rather than an elite audience. Popular culture reflects changes of style, fads, nostalgia, critical revivals, popular institutions, and forms borrowed from elite art, folk art, or foreign culture.
alternative_titles: culture, popular, mass culture, pop culture, Popular Culture

title: privacy
description: The state of being apart from company or observation, generally in voluntary seclusion. Also refers to the right to freedom from unauthorized intrusion.

title: psychology
description: Science of human and animal mind and behavior, both healthy and unhealthy, with the focus on individuals in interaction with their environment.

title: religions
description: Belief systems that encompass various personal and institutional relationships between human beings and what they regard as holy, sacred, or divine, usually but not always a deity, or a spiritual or occult force. Participation in a religion is typically manifested in obedience, reverence, and worship, often including group activities and alliance with a leader. Elements of a religion or similar belief system include doctrine, ritual, defined parameters of morality, and a code of living, often seen as a means of achieving spiritual or material improvement.

title: language
description: The language of the catalog record or other information.

title: traditions
description: A belief or behavior passed down within a group or society with symbolic meaning or special significance with origins in the past. Common examples include holidays or socially meaningful clothes (like laywers' wigs), but the idea has also been applied to social norms such as greetings.

title: visual culture
description: The total of images, objects, and other visuality that has been built up by a group of people and transmitted from one generation to another. It includes art media such as painting, drawing, prints, and installations; architecture and design; utilitarian artifacts of a culture such as tools and costime; media such as photography, film, television, and digital media, covering topics of news, popular culture, advertising and consumerism, politics, law, religion, and science and medicine.
alternative_titles: visual cultures, Visual Culture, Visual Studies

title: archives
description: Collections of historical records and primary source documents that have accumulated over the course of an individual's or organization's lifetime, and are kept to show the function or history of the person or an organization. Documents may be tangible or digital.
alternative_titles: archive, archive collection, archival agency, archive (collection), archive (institution)

title: optics
description: Branch of physics that deals with the properties and phenomena of both visible and invisible light, including its generation, transmission, and detection or perception.

title: film (discipline)
description: Discipline encompassing the art and form of expression of filmmaking and motion pictures, which are produced in the media of film or videotape, on which a series of pictures are presented to the eye in such rapid succession as to give the illusion of natural movement. It may also refer to similar art created in digital media.
alternative_titles: cinema, motion pictures, cinema studies, film studies, film study, cinematography

title: media archaeology
description: Field that attempts to understand new and emerging media through close examination of the past, and especially through critical scrutiny of dominant progressivist narratives of popular commercial media such as film and television. Media archaeologists often evince strong interest in so-called dead media, noting that new media often revive and recirculate material and techniques of communication that had been lost, neglected, or obscured.

title: broadcasts
description: Transmissions of signals, usually taking the form of programs consisting of images and sound, made public by means of television or radio.

title: stereoscopes
description: Viewers in which pairs of stereoscopic images are mounted and appear as a single, three-dimensional image when viewed.

title: search engines
description: A software program that searches the contents of a database based on keywords entered by the user. More specifically, a program that returns a list of URLs from the World Wide Web based on keywords.

title: supercomputing
description: A form of computing that determines or calculates using a high performance computer, a supercomputer, reducing overall time to solution.

title: drawings
description: Visual works produced by drawing, which is the application of lines on a surface, often paper, by using a pencil, pen, chalk, or some other tracing instrument to focus on the delineation of form rather than the application of color. This term is often defined broadly to refer to computer-generated images as well.

title: censorship
description: The act, process, or policy of prohibition of the production, distribution, circulation, or access to a work, or the suppression or deletion of parts of a work, on the grounds that the work contains material or is of an appearance considered politically or morally offensive by some.

title: access
description: The habit, power, state, or faculty of being able to locate, gain entry to, and use something, such as a building or a database. In computer-based information retrieval, access is the method by which a computer refers to records in a file, dependent upon their arrangement.

title: anthropology
description: The scientific study of human history in its biological, linguistic, and social aspects.

title: architecture
description: The art or science of designing and building structures, especially habitable structures, in accordance with principles determined by aesthetic and practical or material considerations.

title: historicism (theory)
description: General theory that emphasizes the importance of history as a standard of value or as a determinant of events.

title: museums
description: Institutions that maintain places where objects of value such as works of art, antiquities, scientific specimens, or other artifacts are housed and displayed for public benefit. An institution devoted to the procurement, care, documentation, study and display of objects of lasting interest or value.

title: music
description: The discipline of combining vocal or instrumental sounds to produce beauty of form, harmony, melody, rhythm, expressive content, etc.; musical composition, performance, analysis, etc., as a subject of study; the occupation or profession of musicians.

title: nanotechnology
description: Development and manufacture of objects 100 nanometers or less in size, or the manipulation of individual molecules and atoms.

title: philosophy
description: Critical examination of the grounds for fundamental beliefs and analysis of the basic concepts, doctrines, or practices that express such beliefs.

title: theory
description: Body of generalizations and principles developed in association with practice in a field of activity and forming its content as an intellectual discipline.

title: history of technology
description: Study of the development of technology over time.

title: science
description: Refers to the group of studies or branches of knowledge concerned with facts and phenomena of the observable or quantifiable world, systematically arranged and showing the operation of general laws.
alternative_titles: sciences, scientific, modern science, modern sciences, Science

title: eyes
description: Paired globular organs of sight in the head of humans and other vertebrates. The term may also refer to any of various visual or light-detecting organs in invertebrates.

title: hands
description: Parts of a human's or an animal's body, usually having fingers, located below the wrist joint of the arms, characterized by being routinely used for purposes other than support and locomotion.

title: imagination
description: The capacity to form or the state of forming mental images or ideas of people, objects, and situations that are not truly present to the senses, including both remembered and constructed ideas and images. In modern philosophy, imagination is the power or capacity by which the mind integrates sensory data in the process of perception.

title: cybersex
description: Virtual sex encounters via electronic video communications (e.g. webcam) and other electronics (such as teledildonics) connected to a computer network.
alternative_titles: cyber sex, computer sex, net sex, cybering

title: digital identity
description: Information on an entity used by computer systems to represent an external agent.

title: ambient intelligence
description: Electronic environments that are sensitive and responsive to the presence of people.

title: artificial intelligence (science discipline)
description: The study of the capacity of machines to simulate human behavior such as reasoning, learning, or the understanding of speech.

title: software manipulations
description: Controlling or influencing computer programs, often but not exclusively clandestine and with malintent.

title: technophobia
description: Fear, discomfort, or aversion to advanced technology, especially computers.

title: digital communities (social network)
description: A community whose members interact with each other primarily via the Internet (e.g. via social media). Members usually share common interests.
alternative_titles: digital community, social networking, virtual community, virtual communities

title: geography
description: Science dealing with the earth and its life, especially the description of land, sea, air, and the distribution of plant and animal life, including human beings, their activities and territorial organizations.

title: environment
description: The natural world or physical surroundings in general, either as a whole or within a particular geographical area, particularly as affected by human activity.
alternative_titles: environmental, natural environment, natural surrounding, natural world

title: bicycles
description: Vehicles with two wheels in tandem propelled by the rider straddling a frame which holds the wheels and handlebars for steering.

title: dolls
description: Figurines representing humans or animals, including but not restricted to those intended as toys for children, usually girls, or as collectibles for adults. Dolls are commonly in the form of a baby or woman, often with changeable clothes; they may have moveable arms and legs. Dolls may be made of cloth (rag dolls), wood, clay, porcelain, wax, paper, plastic, celluloid, corn husks, or other materials. Dolls may also be figurines used for ceremonial, religious, or decorative purposes.

title: flashlights
description: Small, portable electric lamps, usually powered by batteries or a generator.

title: sofas
description: Long, upholstered seating objects with a back and two ends, and primarily used for sitting.

title: tables
description: Articles of furniture consisting of a flat, slablike top supported on one or more legs or supports.

title: animated
description: Giving the illusion of movement that may be created by a number of techniques including successive drawings, photographing positions of puppets or models, or using computers.

title: space
description: Physical extent or area, in two or three dimensions, in the natural world or built environment. Typically used in the context of space being applied to or sufficient for a purpose or action.

title: telephones
description: Instruments, apparatus, or devices that convey or reproduce sounds at a distance, especially such devices in which the human voice is transmitted as by wire, satellite, or via base-station antennas as short-wave analog or digital signals.
alternative_titles: telephone, phones, phone, telephone set, smart phones, smart phone, smartphones, smartphone

title: sight
description: The faculty of perception with the eyes.
alternative_titles: eyesight, vision (sense), visual perception, sense of sight, sensory visual perception, seeing

title: hearing
description: The faculty or sense by which sound is perceived.

title: touch
description: The faculty of perception through physical contact, especially with the fingers.

title: smell
description: The faculty of perceiving odors via the olfactory organs' reception of chemical substances in the surrounding air.
alternative_titles: smell (sense), olfactory perception, sense of smell, olfaction, olfactics

title: telephones (as soundgenerating device)
description: Instruments, apparatus, or devices that convey or reproduce sounds at a distance, especially such devices in which the human voice is transmitted as by wire, satellite, or via base-station antennas as short-wave analog or digital signals.

title: electromagnetism
description: The phenomena associated with electric and magnetic fields and their interactions with each other and with electric charges and currents.
alternative_titles: electromagnetic, electromagnetics, electromagnetic fields, electromagnetic field

title: body tracking
description: Tracking procedures to detect body movements and convert them into a digital format.

title: history
description: Discipline that studies the chronological record of events, such as affecting a nation, community, individual, object, or place, based on a critical examination of source materials and usually presenting an explanation of their causes.

title: product design
description: Creating a new product to be sold by a business to its customers. A very broad coefficient and effective generation and development of ideas through a process that leads to new products. Product design is not the same but overlaps with industrial design, which is concerned with bringing artistic form and usability together in order to mass-produce goods.

title: books
description: Items comprising a collection of leaves of paper, parchment, wood, stiffened textile, ivory, metal tablets, or other flat material, that are blank, written on, or printed, and are strung or bound together in a volume.

title: working class
description: Class of persons employed for wages, usually at manual labor.
alternative_titles: working classes, labouring classes, labouring class, laboring class, laboring classes

title: processual
description: Based on a set of interrelated tasks that transform inputs into outputs. Tasks may be carried out by people, nature or machines using various resources.

title: invention
description: The quality of original and productive creativity.

title: real-time
description: Based on reliable responses to inputs within a specified time interval.

title: simulation
description: The representation of the behavior or characteristics of one system through the use of another system, especially a computer model; often used to forecast or predict the behavior of a dynamic system when real world experimentation is not feasible.
alternative_titles: simulations, simulated, computer simulations, computer simulation

title: television
description: Telecommunication system whereby visual images, with or without accompanying sound, are converted to electromagnetic waves and transmitted to distant receivers where they are reconverted into moving visual images.

title: voyeurism
description: A socially unacceptable pattern of sexual behavior in which one's preferred means of sexual arousal is the clandestine observing of others when they are disrobing, nude, or actually engaging in sexual activity. Arousal is dependent upon the observed person(s) being unaware of their being observed.

title: intimacy
description: Condition of closeness and openness towards another.

title: video (digital)
description: Standardized means of organizing and storing moving images created using a binary numerical system electronically stored in the form of encoded image elements, or pixels.
alternative_titles: digital videos, digital video, digital moving image formats, digital moving image format, digital video formats, digital video format

title: audiotapes
description: Sound recordings on magnetic tape.
alternative_titles: audiotape, audio tapes, audio tape, tape recordings, tape recording, sound tapes, sound tape, phonotapes, phonotape, Compact Cassette, CC, casette tapes, casette tape, tape, tapes, audio casettes, audio casette, audiocasettes, audiocasette

title: ISDN
description: Set of communication standards for simultaneous digital transmission of voice, video, data, and other network services over the traditional circuits of the public switched telephone network.

title: lasers
description: Device which emits light via optical amplification.

title: motion capture
description: Tracking procedure which makes it possible to detect any type of movement and convert it to a digital format.

title: breathing-balance-interface-vest
description: Real-time motion tracking based on breathing and balance.

title: voice analysis
description: Voice analysis is the study of speech sounds for purposes other than linguistic content, e.g. analysis of the voice (phoniatrics) or speaker identification.

title: pain
description: The bodily and emotional experience consisting of physiological and affective responses to an undesirable event. Often serves as a warning mechanism that protects an organism from the threat of injury or potential injury by stimulating a withdrawing response from harmful stimuli.

title: literature
description: General term for the genre of works, written or oral, that are the result or product of literary activity. Included are written works considered collectively; a body of literary works produced in a particular country or period, or of a particular genre.

title: bioart
description: A contemporary art form that adapts scientific methods and draws inspiration from the philosophical, societal, and environmental implications of recombinant genetics, molecular biology, and biotechnology. It features interdisciplinary relationships that blur distinctions between art and science. It may involve biological entities as media.

title: expanded cinema
description: Expanded Cinema broadens the concept and practice of the cinematic. Films are not "only" project onto a screen, it allows for experimental approaches, e.g. multiple projections with several screens, light shows or even multimedia settings in which films, diapositives, overhead projectors and video projections are combined with performative elements like theatre or dance.

title: cybernetics
description: Comparative study of automatic control systems and communication processes in both living organisms and machines. The study links the working of the brain and nervous system with the functioning of computers and automated feedback devices.

title: conceptual art
description: Art from any period in which the idea represented is considered more important than the finished product.

title: performance art
description: Refers to works of art that unfold over time and that combine elements of theater and object-oriented art.

title: video performances
description: Genre in performance art

title: sound performances
description: Genre in performance art in which sound is used as the primary medium or material.

title: performative installations
description: Art installations that put a specific emphasis on performance, e.g. through user interaction.

title: multimedia performances
description: Performances combining and/or juxtaposing varied media from dance to digital technologies.

title: happenings
description: Works that are unique, unrehearsed events, often combining elements of theater, music, and the visual arts. Usually nonverbal, they may incorporate visual, tactile, and olfactory responses, chance, and audience participation. .
alternative_titles: happening, action theater, event art, manifestations (happenings), painter's theater, realizations (happenings), theater of mixed means, total art, total theater, action theatre, painter's theatre, theatre of mixed means, total theatre

title: computer performances
description: Performances that incorporate and integrate computer technologies and techniques.
alternative_titles: computer performance, digital performances, digital performance

title: simulacrum
description: Representation or imitation of a person or thing.

title: sexuality
description: Generally used for the sum of an individual's sexual emotions, ideas, and behavior.

title: manipulation
description: Premeditated action that seeks to controll somebody or something to the own advantage, often with unfair or dishonest conduct.

title: nationalism
description: Sense of national consciousness exalting one nation above all others and placing primary emphasis on promotion of its culture and interests as opposed to those of other nations or supranational groups.

title: symbolism
description: Method of representing things by symbols, or of giving a symbolic character to objects or acts.

title: visualization
description: Making large amounts of complex data comprehensible, usually by using of computer graphics.
alternative_titles: visualizations, visualisation, visualisations, computer visualization, computer visualisation, scientific visualization, scientific visualisation

title: Internet
description: Global computer network which provides the world's users a variety of information resources and communication facilities. It consists of interconnected networks that use standardized communication protocols.
alternative_titles: internet, web, The Internet, www, world wide web, DARPA Internet, Net, net, the Net

title: Modernism
description: Refers to the succession of 20th-century avant-garde art and architectural movements formed in a reaction to social modernity.

title: art history
description: Study of the visual arts within a historical framework, from prehistory to the present, including stylistic development, use of art in communication and decoration, and the aesthetic and intellectual value of art.
alternative_titles: history of art, History of the arts

title: navigable
description: Allowing a certain amount of control.

title: affective
description: Aiming for the experience of feeling or emotion.

title: furniture
description: Movable or fixed objects or equipment, which may be either functional or ornamental, particularly objects for sitting, reclining, or storage, such as chairs, beds, tables, cabinets, etc., in a dwelling, business, or public space.

title: commerce
description: Large-scale organized system related to the exchange of goods and services

title: spectator
description: Individuals who are present at and observe live events, works of art, motion pictures, or architecture.

title: public spaces
description: Open spaces designed for public use or are accesible to the public, often designed to foster a sense of community.
alternative_titles: public space, public places, public place, public areas, public area, public venue, public setting

title: installations
description: Works dating from the 1960s or later that use their exhibition space as part of their design. Demanding a viewer's active engagement, installations are often created by artists in direct opposition to the notion of permanent artwork, or art as a commodity.
alternative_titles: installation, installation works, installation work, installation art, installation artworks, installation artwork

title: art interventions
description: Art works, including performance art, designed specifically to interact with an existing work, structure, environment, or situation, be it another artwork, the audience, an institution, or in the public domain.
alternative_titles: art intervention, intervention, interventions, artistic interventions, artistic intervention

title: game art
description: Game art is an art movement that developed at the beginning of the 21st century and explicitly refers to the virtual space of digital game worlds.

title: glitch art
description: Art genre that uses digital or analog errors for aesthetic purposes.

title: digital activism
description: Use of electronic communication technologies for various forms of activism.
alternative_titles: Digital Activism, Internet activism, cyberactivism, online activism, e-activism, web activism, hacktivism

title: hybrid art
description: Hybrid art is a contemporary art movement in which artists work with frontier areas of science and emerging technologies. Artists work with fields such as biology, robotics, physical sciences, experimental interface technologies, artificial intelligence, and information visualization. They address the research in many ways such as undertaking new research agendas, visualizing results in new ways, or critiquing the social implications of the research.
alternative_titles: Hybrid Art, Hybrid Arts, hybrid arts

title: auditory user interfaces (AUI)
description: Interfaces that rely primarily on audio for interaction, e.g. speech and sound.

title: ludic interfaces
description: Interfaces that are designed to be inherently "playful".

title: internet of things (IoT)
description: Proposed Internet-like structure connecting everyday physical objects.

title: mixed reality-based interaction
description: Merging of virtual and real worlds as foundation for interaction with works of art.

title: facial recognition system
description: Computer application capable of identifying or verifying an individual person from a digital image.
alternative_titles: face recognition, facial recognition, facial recognition system

title: breath based communication
description: Communication that relies on the inhalation and exhalation of air from the lungs.

title: augmented reality interfaces
description: Interface based on the interactive experience of a real-world environment enhanced by computer-generated perceptual information.
alternative_titles: Augmented Reality Interfaces, AR interfaces, AR-interfaces

title: light-emitting diodes (LEDs)
description: Semiconductor diodes that emit visible or infrared light when voltage is applied to them. They are most commonly used as indicator lamps in electronic devices or in automobiles. More recent applications include signage and illumination.
alternative_titles: LED, light-emitting diode, light-emitting diodes, L.E.D., light emitting diodes, light emitting diode, LED's

title: vacuum fluorescent displays (VFD)
description: Electronic display device that operates on the principle of cathodoluminescence.

title: tactile feedback technology
description: Tactile feedback technology can create an experience of touch by applying forces, vibrations, or motions to the user.
alternative_titles: haptic technology, haptic feedback technology, tactile technology

title: headphones
description: Small loudspeakers worn on the head for listening to music or for communications purpose; may have speakers for one or both ears, attached to the head by a band.

title: holography
description: Photographic recording of a light field, rather than of an image formed by a lens, used to display a three-dimensional image of the holographed subject. Processes create three-dimensional appearing images by laser light; when properly viewed, the interference pattern recreates the pattern of light originally reflected by the subject. Allows multiple perspectives such that images in the background are obscured and revealed by those in the foreground as the angle of view changes.

title: electromechanical display devices
description: Output device for the presentation of visual information that is based on electronical and mechanical principles. A well-known electromechanical display device is the split-flap display, which is often used as a public transport timetable, e.g. in airports or railway stations
alternative_titles: Electromechanical Display Device, split-flap display, split flap display

title: electronic paper
description: Display technology that mimics the appearance of ordinary ink on paper
alternative_titles: electronic papers, Electronic Papers, Electronic Paper, e-paper, e-papers, e-ink, electronic ink, electrophoretic display, electrophoretic displays

title: plasma display panels
description: Flat-panel video displays for computers and other such devices that utilize ionized gas, or plasma, to illuminate pixels on the screen which emits a bright light that reflects focused color and images.
alternative_titles: plasma display panel, plasma displays, plasma display, plasma, PDP, PDPs, Plasma Display Panel

title: bodies (as non-electronic displays)
description: Using the body as vital component for an artwork. This also encompass artworks dealing with transhumanism, cyborgism etc.

title: printers
description: Output devices that convert coded information from the processor into a readable form on paper.

title: head-up displays
description: Transparent display presenting data within normal sight lines of the user.
alternative_titles: head-up display, Head-up Displays, Head-up Display

title: paper
description: Refers generally to all types of thin matted or felted sheets or webs of fiber formed and dried on a fine screen from a pulpy water suspension. The fibers may be animal, such as hair, silk or wool, or mineral, such as asbestos, or synthetic. However most paper is made from cellulosic plant fiber, such as from wood pulp, grass, cotton, linen, and straw.

title: globes (as non-electronic displays)
description: Representations of the Earth, heavens, or another planet in the form of a ball.

title: easel paintings
description: Paintings executed on an easel or other portable device, having either canvas or panel supports; generally restricted to those painted from the 16th century forward.
alternative_titles: easel painting, easel-paintings, easel-painting, easel pictures, easel picture, easel-pictures, easel-picture

title: sculptures
description: Three-dimensional works of art in which images and forms are produced in relief, in intaglio, or in the round. The term refers particularly to art works created by carving or engraving a hard material, by molding or casting a malleable material (which usually then hardens), or by assembling parts to create a three-dimensional object. It is typically used to refer to large or medium-sized objects made of stone, wood, bronze, or another metal. For the process use "sculpting".
alternative_titles: sculpture, sculptural work, piece of sculpture

title: tangible acoustic interfaces (TAI)
description: Interfaces that are based on acoustic-sensing technologies, e.g. sound source location and acoustic imaging.

title: touch user interfaces
description: Computer-pointing technology based upon the sense of touch. It enables not only the sense of touch to innervate and activate computer-based functions, it also allows the user, particularly those with visual impairments, an added level of interaction based upon tactile or Braille input.
alternative_titles: tactile user interface, touch user interface, tactile user interfaces

title: radio frequency identification (RFID)
description: System for tracking objects or animals using radio signals. Usually employed via a device such as a microchip which transmits radio signals.
alternative_titles: RFID, Radio Frequency Identification Technology, radio-frequency identification

title: musical instruments
description: Sound-producing apparatuses whose primary function is to play music.

title: turntables
description: Refers to the plates of gramophones or record players on which the recorded discs rest and are spun to draw the grooves of recorded sound under a stylus, at fixed speeds, to enable reproduction of sound. Usage of the term is frequently extended to the totality of the machinery or housing of this plate.
alternative_titles: turntable, phonograph turntables, phonograph turntable, gramophon, gramophones

title: mobile devices
description: Small, hand-held computing devices.
alternative_titles: handheld device, handheld computer, Connected Devices, handheld, Portable communications device, smart phone, smartphones

title: wireless sensor networks (WSN)
description: Refers to networks of autonomous sensor nodes monitoring environmental or physical conditions at diverse locations that pass their data via wireless technology to a central location.
alternative_titles: wireless sensor network, WSNs, WSN, network, wireless sensor

title: optical character recognition (OCR)
description: The process of electronic conversion of handwritten or printed characters into machine-encoded text by means of an optical scanner, special software that identifies text images, and an output interface which reproduces them in electronic form.

title: automatic identification and data capture (AIDC)
description: Methods of automatically identifying objects by computer system.

title: biometrics
description: Statistical study of biological observations and phenomena.

title: plotters
description: Output devices for translating information from computers into pictorial or graphic form on paper or a similar medium.

title: synthesizers
description: Electronic instruments made in a wide variety of models differing considerably in size, appearance, and manner of operation, though generally their output must pass through external amplifiers and loudspeakers to produce sound.
alternative_titles: synthesizer, synth, sound synthesizer, musical synthesizer

title: Global Positioning System (GPS)
description: Refers to the technology originally developed by the U.S. Department of Defense and consisting of 24 satellites that continuously transmit signals globally. In conjunction with receivers on Earth, the system uses triangulation to quickly and accurately determine the latitude, longitude, and altitude of a point on or above the Earth's surface. In addition to military applications, the system is primarily used to gather spatial data needed for making maps and to calculate geographic positions for travelers on Earth who have GPS receivers. The system was originally called "NAVSTAR" (Navigation System with Timing And Ranging).
alternative_titles: global positioning system, GPS, NAVSTAR, Navigation System with Timing And Ranging

title: multimodal interaction
description: Form of human-machine interaction using multiple modes of input/output.
alternative_titles: multi-modal interaction, multimodal interface, multi-modal interface

title: tangible user interfaces (TUI)
description: User interface in which a person interacts with digital information through the physical environment.

title: multi-touchscreens
description: Technology that enables a surface (a touchpad or touchscreen) to recognize the presence of more than one point of contact with the surface at the same time.

title: robotic user interfaces (RUI)
description: Either an interface to a robot, or a robot serving itself as an interface to another system.

title: anamorphic
description: Images so executed as to give a distorted shape to the object represented but which, if viewed from a certain point or using a curved mirror or other instrument, show the object in true proportion.

title: tactile
description: Specially designed for perception through touch.
alternative_titles: tactile values, tactile value, haptic perception, tactile perception, sense of touch, touch perception

title: telematic
description: Based on the long-distance sending and receiving of computerized information.

title: time-based
description: Artworks that are dependent on technology and have a durational dimension.
alternative_titles: time-based works, time-based work, time-based media, time-based media art

title: virtual
description: Artworks that do not exist in the physical world, such as digital art works.
alternative_titles: virtualness, virtuality, virtual works, virtual work

title: visual
description: Works of art, architecture, and any objects that occupy space, are perceived by the sense of sight, and are created or arranged, rather than naturally occurring.
alternative_titles: visual works, visual work, visual artwork, visual artworks, art image, art images

title: duplicated
description: Use of reproduction and copying as a creative tool to achieve aesthetic effects.

title: experimental
description: Application of new methods, ideas, materials, etc. that have not been tried before, usually in order to find out what effect they have.

title: realistic
description: Quality of artworks in which the depiction is based on or seems to be based on the direct observation of the external world, including or even emphasizing flaws and imperfections rather than the beauty or idealized characteristics.

title: automated
description: Using or devising mechanical or electronic devices, processes, or systems which take the place of human effort, observation, or decision, and which require minimal human intervention in their operation.

title: autopoietic
description: Relying on a systems concept which entails automatic reproduction and maintenance.

title: disgusting
description: With the intention to raise strong feelings of disapproval and dislike at a situation, behaviour, etc.

title: distorted
description: Quality or state in a painting or of an object due to the use of optical illusions, manipulated surfaces, or discordantly juxtaposed images.

title: documenting
description: Gathering and recording information, especially to record facts or characteristics or to establish evidence or testimony.

title: interactive
description: Making use of two-way systems involving feedback from a viewer or user to obtain data or commands and to give immediate results or updated information. Generally used to describe computer-based systems, but may have broader applications as well.

title: modular
description: Based on a system of components that can be separated and recombined.

title: multiple
description: Works of art designed to be produced so that there is more than one original, theoretically in unlimited numbers. The most common examples are works produced from plates or negatives, including engravings, etchings, lithographs, photographs, and other prints. Multiples can also be produced from others device or methods, e.g. computer programs.

title: networked
description: Based on a system of interconnected computers or any instances of two or more organisations or individuals engaged in a common pattern of information exchange through automated, online, or on air communications links.

title: olfactory
description: Artworks primarily experienced via the sense of smell.
alternative_titles: odors, odor, aromas, aroma, scents, scent, smells, smell, odours, odour

title: performative
description: Meant to be presented publicly. Art that focuses on presentation, actions, processes rather than producing static objects.
alternative_titles: performances, performance, artist performance, artistic performance

title: polysensory
description: Relating to multiple senses.

title: projected
description: Images cast on a surface or in space by optical means, generally by placing an object between a light source and the surface or a designated point in space. They include images created with slides or film, digital images or other computer files, or shadows cast from opaque objects; projections on surfaces may be cast from the front or the rear of the surface. They also include holograms cast onto a point in space.
alternative_titles: projections, projection, projected images, projection pieces, projection works, projection work

title: found objects
description: Objects, natural or human-made, unaltered or only slightly altered, presented by an artist as works of art in themselves or used as parts of works of art.
alternative_titles: found object, found art, object-art (found objects), readymade, ready-made

title: remediated
description: Representation of one medium in another. New media may revise, repurpose, remix, reference, and/or compete with older media. Remix, one of the tools used most often in remediation, is altering a work from its original state by adding, removing, and/or changing pieces of the item.

title: site-specific
description: Works of the visual arts that are designed for specific locations, especially those that exploit or incorporate aspects of their sites.
alternative_titles: site-specific art, site-specific work, site-specific works, sited works, sited work, site sculpture, site sculptures, site-specific sculpture, site-specific sculptures, site works, site work, site art

title: sonification
description: Using sounds other than speech to convey information or perceptualize data.

title: cybernetic
description: Works of art that are capable of responding to external stimuli.
alternative_titles: cybernetics, cybernetic art, cyberart, cyborg art, post-kinetic art

title: ephemeral
description: Artworks that have a temporal immediacy or are built with the recognition that they will disintegrate.

title: generative
description: Incorporating process in the creation of the artwork. The work itself is usually experienced through time and space, and may include sound, motion, animated graphics, sculptural elements, or any combination of these. Generative art has a performative aspect.

title: gustatory
description: Artworks relying primarily on the sense of taste.

title: hypermediacy
description: Style of visual representation whose goal is to remind the viewer of the medium. Hypermediacy plays upon the desire for immediacy and transparent immediacy, making us hyper-conscious of our act of seeing (or gazing).

title: immersive
description: Giving the perception of being physically present in a non-physical world. The degree of immersion can vary based on the technologies or media that are used to create immersive experiences.

title: mobile
description: Moveable.

title: remixed
description: Piece of media that has been edited and re-released. Remixing is one technique of remediation.

title: sculptural
description: Aesthetics of three-dimensional works of art in which images and forms are produced in relief, in intaglio, or in the round.

title: allegory
description: Method of expressing complex or abstract ideas in the literary or visual arts under the guise of another subject of aptly suggestive resemblance. An allegory is principally constructed from personifications and symbols. In art, allegories include combinations of personifications and/or symbols, which, on the basis of a conventionally agreed relation between concept and representation, refer to an idea outside the work of art. The properties and circumstances attributed to the apparent subject of the allegory really refer to another subject in an extended or continued metaphor. Allegories may have meaning on two or more levels that the viewer or reader can understand only through an interpretive process.

title: anamorphoses
description: Images so executed as to give a distorted shape to the object represented but which, if viewed from a certain point or using a curved mirror or other instrument, show the object in true proportion.

title: animations
description: Works that present the illusion of movement and that may be created by a number of techniques including successive drawings, photographing positions of puppets or models, or using computers.

title: art market
description: Refers to the buying, selling, and trading of works of art.

title: collage
description: Refers to the technique of making compositions in two dimensions or very low relief by gluing paper, fabrics, photographs, or other materials onto a flat surface. The technique is also applied in the digital realm.

title: gaze
description: Psychoanalytical concept and theory surrounding a supposed anxious state that comes with the awareness that one can be viewed: the subject loses a degree of autonomy upon realizing that he or she is a visible object. In the context of art, literature, film, and other arts, a way of regarding people or things so as to embody certain aspects of the relationship between the observer and the observed.

title: grids
description: Networks of horizontal and vertical lines used to guide the layout of graphic material.

title: optical illusion
description: Deceptive visual phenomena induced by the refraction of light as it passes through one substance to another or by atmospheric conditions that manipulate light rays.
alternative_titles: optical illusions, visual illusion, visual illusions

title: mirrors
description: Objects with a highly polished surface, designed to reflect images clearly. The surface is typically smooth, flat, or sometimes slightly curved, made of polished metal in ancient and medieval times, but later usually of glass with a reflective coating on one side.

title: model
description: Something that serves as an ideal, a pattern to follow or copy, or source of inspiration to a creator. Can be physical or conceptual.

title: nude
description: The absence of clothing, leaving those parts of the body that, in the cultural traditions of the viewer, are usually covered, exposed to view. Also an art genre for works that have as their primary subject the unclothed human body.

title: ornaments
description: Decorative forms or embellishments that are an integral part of a building or object but are not essential to its structure. Refers also to decorative objects attached to or worn by humans and animals.
alternative_titles: ornament, ornamentation, adornments, adornment, applied ornament, applied ornaments, applied adorment, applied adorments

title: paintings
description: Unique works in which images are formed primarily by the direct application of pigments suspended in oil, water, egg yolk, molten wax, or other liquid, arranged in masses of color, onto a generally two-dimensional surface.

title: portraits
description: Representations of real individuals that are intended to capture a known or supposed likeness, usually including the face of the person.

title: projections
description: Refers to images cast on a surface or in space by optical means, generally by placing an object between a light source and the surface or a designated point in space. They include images created with slides or film, digital images or other computer files, or shadows cast from opaque objects; projections on surfaces may be cast from the front or the rear of the surface. They also include holograms cast onto a point in space.
alternative_titles: projection, projected images, projection pieces, projection works

title: shadows
description: Areas of partial darkness produced by a body intercepting the direct rays of the sun or other luminary, so that radiation is unable to reach the darkened area directly.

title: sketches
description: Rough or summary art works; less finished than studies. Though sketches are often in the drawing medium, the term "drawings" in general implies more finished works than does "sketches."
alternative_titles: sketch, architectural drawing (sketch), construction drawing (sketch), design drawing

title: still lifes
description: Images in which the focus is a depiction of inanimate objects, as distinguished from art in which such objects are subsidiary elements in a composition. The term is generally applied to depictions of fruit, flowers, meat or dead game, vessels, eating utensils, and other objects, including skulls, candles, and hourglasses, typically arranged on a table. The subject is generally seen in oil paintings, though it can also be found in mosaics, watercolors, prints, collages, and photographs.
alternative_titles: still life, still-life art, still life art, still-lifes, still-life, still live, still lives

title: virtuality
description: Non-physical property of an entity or collection of entities.

title: beauty
description: A pleasing quality associated with harmony of form or color, excellence of craftsmanship, truthfulness, originality, or another, often unspecified, quality.

title: conservation
