description: The action or process of conserving for the preservation of existence, state, life, health, safeguarding from destructive influences, natural decay, or waste. May apply to conserving a building, object, environment, species, or other thing.

title: photography
description: The dedicated practice of making photographs as an applied art.

title: anatomy
description: Discipline concerned with the structure, function, and development of the cells, tissues, and organs constituting the animal body.

title: agency
description: Capacity of an agent to act in a world.

title: performativity
description: The ability of language to effect change in the world.

title: death
description: Cessation of life processes of all living organisms, but particularly refers to the act as it occurs in individual human beings.

title: disease
description: An abnormal, pathological condition that affects part or all of an organism, affecting the functioning of one or more of an organism's systems, parts, or organs. It is often construed as a medical condition associated with specific symptoms and signs.
alternative_titles: diseases, medical disorder, medical disorders, illness, sickness, disease, diseases, ailment, ailments

title: embodiment
description: Representation of a certain quality or idea. Also refers to a theory in cognitive science holding that cognition is shaped by an organism's entire body.

title: physiognomy
description: Study of the interpretation of facial features with respect to qualities of mind or character, shown by peculiarities of configuration or cast or characteristic expression. Can also refer to the general appearance of a person without reference to its implied characteristics.

title: feelings
description: Conscious subjective experience of emotion.

title: skin
description: The layer of tissue forming the external covering of the body in vertebrates.

title: facial expression
description: Motions or positions of subcutaneous (human) face muscles, conveying emotional state.

title: surgery
description: Treating injuries, diseases, pathological conditions, deformities, and other disorders by operative manual and instrumental techniques.
alternative_titles: surgery (health care function), surgical, operating (surgery), surgical procedure, Surgery

title: posthuman
description: Concept originating in the fields of science fiction, futurology, contemporary art, and philosophy that means a person or entity that exists in a state beyond being human.

title: comedy
description: Genre encompassing forms of theatre, literature, and improvisation with the basic objective to amuse, humor, and induce laughter. In general, it is often contrasted with tragedy and can be applied in the form of social criticism through satire and political or intellectual wit or applied in the form of pure spectacle through farce or burlesque.

title: comics
description: Used broadly for sequential graphic narratives, often serialized, and typically having dialogue written in balloons.
alternative_titles: comic (document), comics (documents), funnies, sequential art, ninth art, comic work, comic works

title: entertainment
description: Activity that diverts or amuses someone; causing someone's time to pass agreeably.

title: fashion
description: A prevailing usually short lived custom, usage, or style in clothing, cars, restaurants, or other personal possessions and services.

title: festivals
description: Gala occasions devoted to community observances, such as harvests or anniversaries of notable persons; also cultural events consisting typically of a series of performances of works in the arts.

title: masks
description: Refers to coverings for all or part of the face, usually with openings for the eyes and sometimes the mouth. They are worn to hide or alter the identity of the wearer or for protection. Masks are extremely varied in appearance, function, and fundamental meaning. They may be associated with ceremonies that have religious and social significance or are concerned with funerary customs, fertility rites, or curing sickness. They may be used on festive occasions or to portray characters in a dramatic performance and in re-enactments of mythological events. They may be used for warfare and as protective devices in certain sports. They are also employed as architectural ornaments.
alternative_titles: mask, cultural mask, cultural masks, costume mask, costume masks, art mask, art masks

title: parody
description: The form of analytical criticism in which one performance or work of art or literature subversively mimics another work or its style by adapting and inverting its characteristic features, in order to reveal weaknesses, pretensions, or lack of self-awareness in the original.

title: spectacles
description: Performances and displays on a large scale that are specially prepared or arranged for viewing, usually by the public, with the intent of forming an impressive or interesting show or entertainment.

title: toys
description: Material objects contrived for amusement rather than for practical use by children or pets, or intended as collectibles by adults. Toys are generally miniature versions of real beings or objects that lend themselves to imaginative or imitative play. Toys may also be items for use in games. Among the earliest toys were dolls and balls.

title: phantasmagoria
description: Phantasmagoria was a form of horror theatre that (among other techniques) used one or more magic lanterns to project frightening images, such as skeletons, demons, and ghosts, onto walls, smoke, or semi-transparent screens, typically using rear projection to keep the lantern out of sight.

title: counterculture
description: Subculture whose values and norms of behavior deviate from those of mainstream society. A prominent example is the counterculture of the 1960s.

title: mass culture
description: The dance, literature, music, theater, cinema, television, language, fashion, and other cultural indicators intended for or appreciated by the mainstream public rather than an elite audience. Popular culture reflects changes of style, fads, nostalgia, critical revivals, popular institutions, and forms borrowed from elite art, folk art, or foreign culture.

title: ancestors
description: Those from whom a person is descended, usually considered to be those more remote in the line of descent than grandparents.
alternative_titles: ancestor, forbears, forebears, progenitor, progenitors, ancestress, ancestresses

title: artifacts
description: Generally, objects or other things made or modified by humans, typically manually portable products of human workmanship, such as tools, utensils, objects for personal adornment, or art, as distinguished from natural remains. In archaeology, an artifact is an object made by a human culture and later recovered by an archaeological endeavor.

title: cultural heritage
description: The belief systems, values, philosophical systems, knowledge, behaviors, customs, arts, history, experience, languages, social relationships, institutions, and material goods and creations belonging to a group of people and transmitted from one generation to another. The group of people or society may be bound together by race, age, ethnicity, language, national origin, religion, or other social categories or groupings.
alternative_titles: cultural legacy, culture legacy, cultural asset

title: nostalgia
description: State of wistful yearning to return to a former place or time.

title: preservation
description: The maintenance of objects as closely as possible to their original condition through appropriate environmentally controlled collection maintenance, repair, and physical treatment. Refers to actions taken to prevent further changes or deterioration in objects, sites, or structures. More generally, for the treatment, preventive care, and research directed toward the long-term safekeeping of cultural and natural heritage, see "conservation."

title: romanticism
description: Refers to the European movement affecting visual arts, literature, music, and to a lesser degree architecture from the mid-18th to the mid-19th centuries. Viewed as a reaction to Neoclassical formality, it stressed emotion and the right to individual expression. Works encompass a range of styles but in general are painterly, dynamic, and reflect an interest in color over line.
alternative_titles: Romantic (modern European styles), Romanticist, Romantic movement, romantic era, romantic period

title: memorial
description: Area or object, smaller than a monument, which serves as a focus for memory of something.

title: collective memory
description: Shared pool of memories, knowledge and information of a social group that is significantly associated with the group's identity.
alternative_titles: collective memories, social memory, social memories

title: teleology
description: Philosophical study of finality, especially as it pertains to design or purposes in the processes of nature.

title: modern era
description: Era from ca. 1500 until present.
alternative_titles: modern period, modern age, modern times, modern history

title: postcolonialism
description: The historical-political-cultural nexus of the global colonial experience and its aftermath in the late 20th century and beyond; it embraces the colonial past, the present time following the end of colonial status in a given region, the exile and diaspora of colonized and colonizing peoples, and the politics of multiculturalism.
alternative_titles: post-colonialism, postcolonial, Postcolonialism, postcolonial studies, postcolonial theory

title: psychedelic
description: Advocation of the exploration of the subconscious mind through drugs, sensory deprivation, and a total immersion of the senses through music and light shows. In the visual arts, the style is characterized by obsessively detailed images, ambiguous representations of space, and acidic colors.
alternative_titles: psychedelia, Acid Art, Dayglo Art, Psychedelic Art

title: sorcery
description: Form of white magic and black magic.

title: supernaturalism
description: The study of entites or phenomena that are thought to be beyond the laws of nature.

title: superstition
description: Belief in irrational supernatural causality.

title: uncanny
description: Psychological experience of something as strangely familiar.

title: esoterism
description: Wide range of loosely related ideas and movements associated with the occult or secrets.

title: animism
description: Refers to the belief in spiritual beings capable of influencing human events, based on the idea that animals, plants and even inanimate objects have souls like humans.

title: metaphysics
description: Branch of philosophy inquring into the fundamental nature of reality, including such concepts as being, substance, essence, time, space, cause, and identity.

title: ghosts
description: Souls of deceased persons, spoken of as appearing in a visible form, or otherwise manifesting their presence, to the living.

title: telepathy
description: Telepathy is the purported vicarious transmission of information from one person's mind to another's without using any known human sensory channels or physical interaction.

title: video surveillance
description: Closed-circuit television specifically for surveillance purposes.

title: big data
description: Information assets characterized by such a high volume, velocity, and variety to require specific technology and analytical methods for its transformation into value.

title: error messages
description: Message displayed on a monitor screen or printout indicating that an incorrect instruction has been given or that there is an error resulting from faulty software or hardware.
alternative_titles: error messages, fault message, fault messages

title: global village
description: Global village describes the phenomenon of the entire world becoming more interconnected as the result of the propagation of media technologies throughout the world.

title: hypertext
description: Generally, hypertext is any collection of written or pictorial matter that may be experienced non-sequentially, specifically used now in relation to the World Wide Web.

title: information
description: Data, ideas, and imaginative works that have been communicated, recorded, published and/or distributed formally or informally in any format.

title: media theory
description: Theories of media and communication, usually (but not exclusively) they are explored within the discipline media studies and often approach the relationship between people and media.

title: radio
description: Telecommunication system whereby sound and code signals are transmitted through space without wires by means of radio frequency electromagnetic waves.
alternative_titles: radiocommunication, radiocommunications, radio communication, radio communications

title: telecommunications
description: Science of communication over long distances, especially by electronic means, such as telephone systems or broadcasting.

title: writing
description: Forming or producing letters to record the ideas which characters and words express or to communicate the ideas by visible signs.

title: advertising
description: Public presentation of or calling attention to a product, service, event, or idea, that is openly paid for by an identified entity. Media for advertising include print and online publications, posters, television, and other media.

title: print media
description: Written or pictorial form of communication produced mechanically or electronically using printing, photocopying, or digital methods from which multiple copies can be made through automated processes. In a narrower sense, any form of ‘ink and paper’ communication that is not hand-written or hand-typed, including books, circulars, journals, lithographs, memos, magazines, newspapers, pamphlets, and periodicals.

title: electronic media
description: Media that use electronics or electromechanical energy for the audience to access the content.

title: nonhuman communication
description: Any form of communication outside of the human realm.

title: social media
description: Refers to tools, usually a combination of software and database accessible through the World Wide Web, which enable persistent computer-mediated relationships that encompass social networking, blogs, wikis, and social or collaborative tagging.

title: vegetation
description: Plants collectively, usually referring to plants or vegetal growths in a defined area.

title: atmosphere
description: The gas and aerosol envelope that extends from the ocean, land, and ice-covered surface of a planet outward into space; used especially in reference to the earth where it is held by the force of gravity.

title: ecology
description: Branch of biology dealing with the relations and interactions between organisms and their habitat, including other organisms.
alternative_titles: ecosystems, ecological, ecological system, ecological systems

title: four elements
description: Group of four elements (fire, earth, water, air) into which according to ancient notions any object may be analyzed

title: pollution
description: The introduction of or condition of having harmful or otherwise undesirable substances or products in the environment.

title: global warming
description: The gradual increase over time of the average temperature of the entire earth's lower atmosphere. Global warming has occurred in the distant past as the result of natural influences, but the term is most often used to refer to the warming predicted to occur as a result of emissions of greenhouse gases directly and indirectly caused from the burning of fossil fuels. An increase of the earth's temperature by only a few degrees results in dramatic climate change, loss of habitat and species, sea-level rise, and alteration of the oceans' currents.
alternative_titles: climate change, climate crisis, climate catastrophy, climate emergency

title: magnetism
description: Class of physical phenomena associated with magnets and the fields of force produced by moving electric currents.

title: catastrophes
description: Sudden calamitous events producing great material damage, loss, or distress.
alternative_titles: catastrophe, disasters, disaster, calamities, calamity, cataclysms, cataclysm

title: energy
description: Generally, the capacity to do work; precisely, any quantity with dimensions that can be represented as mass times length squared divided by time squared.

title: agriculture
description: Science or discipline of cultivating the soil, harvesting crops, and raising livestock.

title: oceans
description: Category of marine body of water comprising the main water areas of the earth, lying in basins.

title: sustainability
description: The preservation of natural or cultural resources through managed use. For example, as an ecological concept, the preservation of natural resources through responsible use and stewardship; a component of sustainable development. In context of conservation, preserving cultural heritage resources through maintenance and limited use.
alternative_titles: sustainable use, sustainable, ecological sustainability, environmental sustainability

title: physical laws
description: Scientific law of physics.
alternative_titles: physical law, physical principle, physical principles, law of physics, laws of physics

title: authority
description: Authority is the legitimate power of a person or group over other people. In a civil state, authority is practiced in ways such a judicial branch or an executive branch of government.

title: colonialism
description: The political phenomenon that occured from ca. 1500, whereby European nations conquered and exploited the peoples in other parts of the world. Often used generally, and in a derogatory manner, referring to a policy of control by one country over another group or area.

title: conspiracies
description: Events involving multiple people reaching agreement or working together for an evil or unlawful purpose, such as treason, sedition, murder, or other serious wrong doing.
alternative_titles: conspiracy, political conspiracy, political conspiracies, complot, complots

title: discrimination
description: Biased or differential attitudes toward or treatment of people on the basis of the group, class, or category to which they belong.

title: geopolitics
description: Study of the geographic aspects of political phenomena, including the geographical bases of the power of nations, and geographic influences on power relationships in international politics.

title: governance
description: All of the processes of governing, whether undertaken by a government, market or network, whether over a family, tribe, formal or informal organization or territory and whether through the laws, norms, power or language of an organized society.

title: heroism
description: Great courage. Acts of bravery.

title: human rights
description: Rights deemed by a society to be possessed by all humans, typicaly a set of entitlements held to be critical by virtue of being human.

title: imperialism
description: Creation of an unequal relationship between states through domination

title: markets
description: Congregations of people at a stated time and place for the purpose of private buying and selling, usually not by auction.

title: military
description: Refers in the aggregate to military, naval and air forces of any nation.
alternative_titles: military force, military forces, military affairs, army, armed services, armed service, defence forces, defense forces

title: sovereignty
description: Supreme and independent authority of a political unit to make and apply laws within its own boundaries and to conduct international relations.

title: terrorism
description: Systematic use of terror, violence, and intimidation against people, usually civilians, or property to create a general climate of fear in a population. The purpose of terrorism is typically to bring about a particular political or social objective.

title: warfare
description: Conduct of war, often including the weapons and methods that are used.
alternative_titles: war, wars, armed conflict, armed conflicts

title: love
description: Emotional and psychological state based on strong affection, loyalty, and benevolence for another arising out of kinship, as in maternal love; arising out of sexual attraction and emotional affinity, as in affection and tenderness felt between lovers; and arising out of respect and admiration, as in the valuation and appreciation among friends.

title: affect
description: Experience of feeling or emotion.

title: alienation
description: Of a person, or his or her feelings: estranged, excluded, or turned away (from a person or thing); experiencing a feeling of estrangement or isolation. Also in extended use: (of a period, place, etc.) characterized by or inducing such feelings.

title: anger
description: Strong emotional reaction of displeasure or hostility demonstrated by physical reactions, particular facial grimaces and body positions characteristic of action in the autonomic nervous system.

title: stress
description: Resultant condition of applied force; condition existing in a body when its internal structure or surfaces resist a force that produces or tends to produce deformation in the body.

title: cognition
description: Mental processes by which knowledge is acquired. These include knowing, perceiving, reasoning and problem-solving.
alternative_titles: cognitive ability, cognitive abilities, human cognition, cognitive process, cognitive processes

title: curiosity
description: Desire to learn, explore, or investigate.

title: depression
description: State of low mood and aversion to activity, which can affect a person's thoughts, behavior, motivation, feelings, and sense of well-being.

title: disgust
description: Strong feeling of disapproval and dislike at a situation, person's behaviour, etc.

title: ecstasy
description: Advanced emotion, subjective experience of total involvement of the subject, with an object of their awareness.

title: empathy
description: The capacity for participating in, or a vicarious experiencing of, another's feelings, volitions, or ideas.

title: erotic
description: Refers to the emotional, intellectual, and physiological condition of sexual arousal. Use also for the capacity or quality of inspiring such arousal through suggestion, symbolism, or allusion.
alternative_titles: eroticism, Eroticsm, arousal, sexual, erotism, sexual arousal, sexual excitement

title: experience
description: Subjective interpretation of perceptible stimuli by an individual.

title: fear
description: The state of alarm and urgency; apprehension toward a potentially harmful experience.

title: happiness
description: The personal state of pleasurable contentment of mind, typically including contentment with or resignation to one's circumstances.

title: isolation
description: To set something apart from others. In some contexts, to identify something and examine or deal with it separately.

title: joy
description: Emotion expressing the mental state of happiness, bliss, and felicity.

title: narcissism
description: Personality trait of self-love of a perceived perfect self.

title: optimism
description: Positive mental attitude.

title: perception
description: The process of becoming aware of objects, qualities, or relations via the sense organs; involves the reception, processing, and interpretation of sensory impressions.

title: pessimism
description: Mental attitude and philosophical position that dwells on the dark or gloomy side of things, the world or the universe, culminating in a sense of their vanity and nothingness that is sometimes thought to render them unworthy of existence.

title: pleasure
description: The state of emotional, mental, or physical gratification. Also refers to the source of joy or amusement.

title: psychoanalysis
description: The science concerning the relation of conscious and unconscious psychological processes; also a particular method of investigation of unconscious mental processes, designed to bring preconscious and unconscious material to the patient's consciousness in order to treat behavioral and personality disorders.

title: sadness
description: A pensive psychological state characterized by despair and dejection.

title: self awareness
description: Capacity for an individual to consciously know and understand one's own character, feelings, motives, and desires.

title: shame
description: The painful emotion arising from the consciousness of something dishonoring, ridiculous, or indecorous in one's own conduct or circumstances of being in a situation which offends one's sense of modesty or decency.

title: shock
description: A sudden, unexpected, and usually unpleasant event or experience. In medicine a condition of insufficient blood flow to the tissues of the body.

title: trust
description: Assumption of and reliance on the honesty of another party.

title: psychosis
description: Abnormal condition of the mind that involves hallucinations and delusions and is a symptom of any of various disorders or other causes.

title: paranoia
description: Thought process believed to be heavily influenced by anxiety or fear, often to the point of delusion and irrationality.

title: unconsciousness
description: The state, in a normally conscious being, of not being conscious.

title: mental disorders
description: General term for any emotional or organic mental impairments, manifested in maladaptive behavior, psychological problems, or impairment in one or more significant areas of functioning.
alternative_titles: mental disorder, mental illness, mental pathology, mental disease, mental diseases

title: loneliness
description: Unpleasant emotional response to isolation.

title: anxiety
description: Refers to the irrationally-based feeling of apprehension or dread, a product of internal emotional or psychological conflicts. The feeling can be situation-specific, chronic, or general and diffuse. Often associated with Freudian ideas of suppressed feelings and impulses and with the idea of learned or conditioned response mechanism in which the anxiety is triggered by events or stimuli associated with circumstances that previously produced a frightening or stressful experience.

title: amnesia
description: Cognitive disorder where the memory is disturbed or lost and involves the loss of memories previously established, loss of the ability to create new memories, continuous high blood pressure and severe shock may also caused amnesia.

title: Islam
description: Refers to the religious beliefs and social practices founded in the seventh century by the Arabian Prophet Muhammad, held to be the last of a series of major prophets, which include, according to Islamic dogma, Adam, Noah, and Jesus. It later spread throughout the Middle East, Africa, Europe, and parts of Asia. It is characterized by the belief in the fundamental idea that a devotee 'surrenders' and submits his will to Allah, the prime creator and sustainer of the universe and all creation. In Islam, God is unique and has no partner or intermediary as in the Christian Trinity. Social service and the active alleviation of suffering in others is considered the only path to salvation and prayer and sacred ritual alone are inadequate forms of submission to Allah. The Qur'an (Koran), the sacred text of the religion, is a compilation of revelations from Allah believed to have been received by Muhammad.
alternative_titles: Islamic religion, Islamism, Mohammedan, Mohammedanism, Moslem, Muhammadanism, Muslim, Muslimism, Mussulmanism, mahométanisme, islamisme, Muslim religion, al-’islām

title: Buddhism
description: Refers to the philosophy and religion based on the enlightenment and teachings of the Buddha Gautama in the early sixth century BCE in the northeastern region of modern India. Playing dominant roles in the art and culture of Southeast Asia and East Asia, this religion is based on the transcendence of human suffering and pain through the acceptance of the limitations of individuality, the surrender of worldly desires and cravings that cause disappointment and sorrow, and the deliverance from the impermanence of living and individual ego based on wealth, social position, or family through the process of enlightenment (nirvana). The religion also centers around 'anatman', or no-self, the idea that the self is in a state of action or a series of changing manifestations rather than in a state of fixed, metaphysical substance. The structure of the religion is based on the Triratna ("Three Jewels" of Buddha), a tripartite schematic for living based on three elements: Buddha (the teacher), dharma (the teaching), and sangha (community).

title: Judaism
description: Refers to the monotheistic religion of the Jewish people, central to which is the belief that the ancient Israelites experienced God's presence in human events. Jews believe that the one God delivered the Israelites out of bondage in Egypt, revealed the structure of communal and individual life to them, and chose them to be a holy nation of people able to set an example for all humankind. The Hebrew Bible and Talmud are the two primary sources for Judaism's spiritual and ethical principles. The religion, which traces its origins to Abraham, places more emphasis on expressing beliefs through ritual rather than through abstract doctrine. The Sabbath, beginning on sunset on Friday and ending at sunset on Saturday, is the central religious observance; there is also an annual cycle of religious festivals and days of fasting. Judaism has had a diverse history of development over almost 4000 years, with a number of resulting branches in modern times, namely Orthodox, Conservative, and Reform.

title: creation
description: The bringing into existence of the world or universe, usually by a deity or supernatural force, either making the universe out of nothing, or fashioning pre-existing materials into the universe. As defined by many historical and some current religions, the beginning of the world as an event from which the reckoning of time begins. Most modern religions reconcile the doctrine with scientific theory by treating the literary tradition of creation stories, such as in the Bible, as allegory, while some consider the literary tradition of creation as fact.

title: afterlife
description: The idea of survival of a person in some form after physical death. This notion is present in a wide variety of forms in different religions.

title: exodus
description: The departure of the Hebrew slaves from Egypt under the leadership of Moses. Also the second of the Books of Moses in the Old Testament of the Bible. For exodus in the sense of mass emigration please use "migration" in the subject facet "Society and Culture".

title: rituals
description: Generally, practices or patterns of behavior regularly performed in a set, precise manner, for either personal or public purposes. Specifically, particular activities performed during a designated event, often a ceremony.

title: sacrifices
description: Offerings to a deity, for the purpose of propitiation or homage, usually something of value, material or immaterial; human, animal, or other living agent or object.
alternative_titles: sacrifice, sacrificed, sacrificial rite, sacrifice ritual, sacrificial ritual

title: spirituality
description: In modern times the term broadened to refer to a wider range of experiences, including a range of esoteric and religious traditions.

title: visions
description: Experiences in which a person, thing, or event appears vividly or credibly to the mind, although not actually present.

title: worship
description: The reverent love and allegiance accorded a deity, idol, or sacred object, often expressed through ceremonies, prayers, or other religious rituals.

title: paradise
description: Place or state of perfect freedom, peace, innocence, and plenty, often referred to both as the original state of humanity and a blissful world to come. Common to many religions and mythologies.

title: Bibles
description: Refers to books, scrolls, rolls, or other document forms containing the sacred scriptures of Judaism or Christianity. Bibles may also contain illuminations, which are painted scenes or decorations. The Bible is composed of two parts: The Hebrew scriptures or Old Testament, written originally in Hebrew (with some parts in Aramaic) and including the writings of the Jewish people, and the New Testament, composed in Greek and recording the story of Jesus and the beginnings of Christianity. The Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox versions of the Old Testament are somewhat larger than the Protestant Bible because they accept certain books and parts of books considered apocryphal by Protestants. The Jewish Bible includes only the books known to Christians as the Old Testament. The arrangements of the Jewish and Christian canons differ considerably. Traditionally the Jews have divided their scriptures (the Old Testament) into three parts: The Torah (the "Law"), or Pentateuch; the Nevi'im (the "Prophets"); and the Ketuvim (the "Writings"), or Hagiographa. The stories, moral teachings, and theological doctrines in the bible have provided subjects for an immense body of visual art in both Christian and Jewish imagery. For Christians, a canon of biblical books was established in the Early Christian period; however, several apocryphal books continued to circulate long afterwards. Beginning in the late medieval period, poetic and dramatic interpretations of biblical narratives were very popular, providing ample extra-canonical literature that contributed to the development of important subjects in Christian art.
alternative_titles: Bible, Holy Bible, The Holy Bible, Holy Scriptures, Judaeo-Christian Bible, Christian scriptures, bible, bibles

title: Christianity
description: Refers to the world religion and culture that developed in the first century CE, driven by the teachings of Jesus Christ of Nazareth. Its roots are in the Judaic tradition and the Old Testament. The tenets include a belief in the death and redemptive resurrection of Jesus. The religion incorporates a tradition of faith, ritual, and a form of church authority or leadership.

title: crucifixions
description: To put to death by nailing or otherwise fastening to a cross; an ancient mode of capital punishment among Asians, Greeks, Romans, and other peoples. In Greek and Roman culture, was considered an especially ignominious means of execution.

title: sin
description: Acts or thoughts that are transgressions of the divine law and an offence against God, or are a deliberate violation of some religious or moral principle.

title: heretic
description: Believer, deviating from accepted doctrine.

title: astronomy
description: The science that deals with the material universe beyond the earth's atmosphere, comprising the study of celestial objects and extraterrestrial phenomena, and of the nature and history of the universe.

title: biology
description: The study of living organisms, including their structure, functioning, origin and evolution, classification, interrelationships, and distribution.
alternative_titles: biological, biological science, biological sciences, bio

title: botany
description: The scientific study of all plant life, including their structure, properties, and biochemical processes.
alternative_titles: botanical, botanical science, plant science, plant sciences, plant biology

title: experiments
description: Scientific procedure carried out to support, refute, or validate a hypothesis.

title: geometry
description: Branch of mathematics dealing with the measurement, relationships and properties of points, lines, curves, angles, surfaces, and solid figures.

title: history of science
description: Study of scientific concepts and practice throughout human history in a global, social, and cultural context.

title: libraries
description: Collections of books, periodicals, and other materials, organized to provide physical, bibliographic, and intellectual access by the public or members of a group.

title: neuroscience
description: Scientific study of the nervous system.

title: physics
description: Science that studies the laws determining the structure of the observable universe and the interaction between its fundamental constituents, such as matter and energy, with the broad goal of explaining natural phenomena.

title: research
description: Conducting diligent and systematic inquiry or investigation into a subject or question, especially in order to discover or revise facts or theories.

title: statistics
description: Branch of mathematics that deals with the collection and arrangement of numerical facts or data,whether relating to human affairs or to natural phenomena.

title: humanities
description: Branches of learning regarded as having primarily a cultural character, such as languages, literature, and philosophy.

title: evidence
description: Evidence which either supports or counters a scientific theory.

title: activism
description: Efforts to make change in society toward a perceived greater good.

title: capitalism
description: Economic system characterized by private or corporate ownership of capital goods, by investments that are determined by private decision rather than state control, and by prices, production, and the distribution of goods that are determined mainly by competition in a free market.

title: civilization
description: Generally, a relatively high level of cultural and technological development in human society. Specifically, the stage of cultural development at which writing and the keeping of written records is attained.

title: consumption
description: Purchase and use of goods and services.

title: diversity
description: The condition of having elements that are different, varied, or unlike. Used often to describe organizational or social groups composed of different types of people with varying perspectives.

title: economy
description: The management or administration of the money, financial resources, or material resources of a community, a nation, or the world.
alternative_titles: economies, economic system, economic systems, economy system, economy systems

title: equality
description: The condition or ideal of uniformity in treatment, status, dignity, rank, or privileges, particularly as recognized by those in a society who are in a position to affect or influence these standards.

title: morality
description: Ethical wisdom, knowledge, or qualities, as evidenced in behavior conforming to moral law or accepted moral standards, particularly in relation to sexual matters or personal qualities judged to be good.

title: ethnicity
description: The perception of identity, distinctiveness, and significance of a group that shares a linguistic group, religious belief, nationality, cultural tradition, or perceived physiological characteristics.
alternative_titles: ethnic, ethnic group identity, ethnic identity, ethnicity theory

title: feminism
description: Social and political critical theory and movement asserting the inherent value of women and female characteristics, and working to protect and promote women's rights and interests.
alternative_titles: feminist (cultural movement), feminist movement, women's liberation movement, women's movement, gender equality

title: globalization
description: Refers to the global integration of economic, political, cultural and social institutions as motivated by objectives which include fostering international cooperation and coordination, universalizing regulatory standards, and enabling free flow of capital and free trade. The term is also used to imply the loss of national identity that globalization is perceived to bring.

title: information society
description: An information society is a society where the usage, creation, distribution, manipulation and integration of information is a significant activity.

title: mass society
description: Mass society is a concept that describes modern society as a monolithic force and yet a disaggregate collection of individuals.

title: migration
description: The function of moving from one country, region, or place to settle in another.
alternative_titles: human migration, emigration, immigration, migratory movement (demography)

title: minorities
description: Smaller groups within a larger society that are the objects of prejudice or discrimination from the majority.

title: native
description: The original, or earliest known, inhabitants of a colony or country.
alternative_titles: indigenous people, indigenous peoples, indigenous person, indigenous persons, native people, native peoples, aboriginal people, aboriginal peoples, indigenous population, aborgine, aborigines, indigene, indigenes, indigenous culture

title: otherness
description: Process of differentiation and demarcation where an in-group construes one or many out-groups with the intention to draw the line between "them" and "us". "Othering" understands this process as an underlying cultural process, which maintains these boundaries.

title: participation
description: Inclusion of individuals and organizations in decision-making and opinion-forming processes.

title: patriarchies
description: The provinces or jurisdictions of a patriarch.

title: poverty
description: The condition of having little or no wealth or material possessions.

title: racism
description: Discriminatory attitudes and denial of rights, privileges, or choice because of race.

title: unemployment
description: The state of being without a paying job.

title: wealth
description: All property or resources that have monetary or exchangeable value or economic utility.

title: individuality
description: Characteristic that contributes to the differentiation or distinction of someone or something from a group of otherwise comparable identity.

title: banking
description: Business of receiving and safeguarding money on deposit, loaning money, extending credit, and facilitating the transfer of funds by check, draft, or exchange.
alternative_titles: banking industry, bank industry, economics of banking, banking sector

title: cartography
description: The science and practice of calculation and representation of a geographical area, usually on a flat surface such as a map or chart. It may involve the physical or geographical features, superimposition of political, cultural, or other non-geographical divisions, or the distribution of socio-economic, political, agricultural, meteorological, or other information. Each point in the representation will correspond to an actual geographical position according to a fixed scale or projection. The term map also apply to those who study and calculate similar representations of the positions of stars, planets, the surface of other planet, or the like.
alternative_titles: cartographic, chartography, cartographic science, mapping (cartography discipline)

title: territories
description: Divisions under the jurisdiction of a nation, not vested with the full authority of provinces or states, but having some degree of local governing and legislative power.
alternative_titles: territory, territorial region, territorial entity, geographic area

title: countries
description: Independent states, or regions once independent and still distinct in race, language, institutions, or historical memories. For example, England, Scotland, and Northern Ireland are countries in the nation of the United Kingdom.

title: borders
description: Boundary lines that separate one country from another.
alternative_titles: border, state boundary, state boundaries, state border, state borders

title: topography
description: The art or practice of the accurate graphic delineation of the natural and man-made surface features of a specific urban area, tract of land, or other place, especially so as to show their relative positions and elevations.

title: cyberspace
description: Computer science concept of a place within the collective memories and interconnecting networks of computers filled with virtual 'stuff' and populated by people with virtual bodies. Distinguished from "virtual reality" which is an immersive virtual physical environment with user interfaces.

title: three-dimensional
description: Having, or appearing to have, the three dimensions of length, width, and height.

title: development
description: Change over time in human activities, institutions, or settlements, usually in the sense of improvement or expansion.

title: digitization
description: Converting, sound, motion pictures, images, or other analog data to binary form to be stored or altered with a computer.

title: emulation
description: Technique by which one computer is enabled to interpret and execute the instruction set of another.

title: engineering
description: The discipline of applying technical, scientific, and mathematical knowledge to the design and construction of architecture, machines, systems, processes, and the like.

title: innovation
description: Application of better solutions that meet new requirements, inarticulated needs, or existing market needs.

title: mechanics
description: Study of forces on matter or systems, involving the identification and description of such systems by cause-and-effect associations.

title: mobility
description: The ability to move via vehicles and services.

title: open source
description: Philosophy about free redistribution and access to a product.
alternative_titles: open source code, open source model, open src, open code, open-source

title: telematics
description: Science of the long-distance sending and receiving of computerized information.

title: telepresence
description: Set of technologies which allow a person to feel as if they were present in another place.

title: military technology
description: Application of technology for use in warfare.

title: horoscope
description: A diagram indicating position of planets and zodiacs with respect to time and place of birth of a person.

title: enchantment
description: Magic effect that was put on something or someone.

title: legends
description: Stories handed down by tradition from earlier times, usually concerned with a real person, place, or event, and popularly regarded as historical although not entirely verifiable.
alternative_titles: legend, legends (literary genre), legend (literary genre), folk tale, folk tales

title: fantasy
description: Ideas having to do solely with the spectacular and improbable, with no or very little relationship to real people, objects, or events.

title: illusion (performing art)
description: Performing art focusing on sleight of hand or tricks involving various types of illusion for purposes of entertainment.
alternative_titles: magic trick, magic tricks, magic (performing art), conjuring performance, conjuring trick, art of illusion (performing art)

title: occultism
description: Includes references to or interest in hidden, mysterious, or supernatural powers, as manifested in all fields of human endeavor or creativity.

title: collaborative
description: Focus on participation and working together.

title: materiality
description: Putting the substances, or raw ingredients of an artwork in the foreground (rather than for the idea for example).

title: mythological creatures
description: Living or animate beings, including animals or people that are fantastic or of anomalous or uncertain aspect or nature.
alternative_titles: mythological creature, mythical creature, mythical creatures

title: anthropomorph
description: Attribution of human traits, emotions, or intentions to non-human entities.

title: personification
description: Artistic device that consists of attributing and granting human characteristics to an abstract quality, animal, or inanimate object.

title: anthropocentrism
description: Position that human beings are the central species, or the assessment of reality through an exclusively human perspective.

title: saints
description: People recognized by others as holy persons; in various religions, the dead who are believed to be in Heaven. In the Roman and Eastern Catholic churches, people who are formally recognized by the Church as having had exceptional holiness of life and therefore an exalted station in heaven, and who have often been formally canonized.
alternative_titles: saint, Saint, St., St, hallow, holy, holy person

title: mysticism
description: Refers in a general sense to a spiritual quest for hidden truth, the goal of which is to be united with the divine. It also refers more specifically to a belief in the existence of important realities beyond perceptual or intellectual understanding that are accessible by subjective experience, such as by intuition or meditation. Forms of mysticism are found in all major religions as well as in secular experience.

title: alchemy
description: A form of chemistry and speculative philosophy practiced in the Middle Ages and the Renaissance and concerned principally with discovering methods for transmuting base metal into gold and with finding a universal solvent and an elixir of life.

title: electricity
description: Physical phenomenon involving electric charges and their effects when at rest and in motion.

title: sculpting
description: Refers to the process or branch of fine art concerned with creating sculpture, which are three-dimensional works. It refers particularly to carving or engraving a hard material, or with molding or casting a malleable material, so as to produce designs or figures in relief, in intaglio, or in the round. It is typically used to refer to the production of large or medium-sized objects in stone, clay, or bronze.

title: mythologies
description: The body of mythical stories or traditional beliefs belonging to a particular religious or cultural tradition; usage often differs from standard religions only in that the belief system is no longer extant.

title: representation of knowledge
description: Set of tools used to represent and organize human knowledge in order to use or share it.

title: churches
description: Institutions that maintain places for public Christian worship.

title: plants
description: Multicellular eukaryotic life forms characterized by photosynthesis, in which chemical energy is produced from water, minerals, and carbon dioxide with the aid of pigments and the radiant energy of the Sun. However, also included in the kingdom are plants that do not produce their food by photosynthesis, but rather are parasitic and live off of other living plants. Other plants are saprophytic, obtaining their food from dead organic matter. Plants have cells that contain cellulose in their walls and are therefore to some extent rigid. There is also an absence of organs of locomotion, resulting in a more or less stationary existence as well as no sensory and nervous systems. There are over 300,000 living species of plants.

title: software
description: Computer system programs, procedures, and associated documentation concerned with the operation of data processing systems, and which require hardware for use to be made of them.

title: hardware
description: The physical components of a computer system or device as opposed to the software required for its operation.

title: video (analog)
description: Type of electrical signals. Also older video recording formats.

title: body sensors
description: Data aquisition systems to retrieve various physiological information from animal bodies. The connection of a group of sensors is called "Body Sensor Network".

title: soundgenerating devices
description: Tools and equipment to generate sound.

title: radio frequency identification (RFID)
description: System for tracking objects or animals using radio signals. Usually employed via a device such as a microchip which transmits radio signals.
alternative_titles: RFID, Radio Frequency Identification Technology, radio-frequency identification, radio frequency identifier

title: interactive media
description: Media requiring interaction from the user to be understood, executed, or experienced.

title: voice user interfaces (VUI)
description: Enables spoken human interaction with computers by using speech recognition to understand spoken commands and answer questions.
alternative_titles: voice user interface, VUI, Voice User Interface

title: medicine (discipline)
description: Discipline concerned with the study of human diseases and injuries, including their causes, treatment, and prevention, and with the diagnosis and management of patients.

title: immaterial
description: Exploration of the non-material realm in various domains, e.g. in philosophy the soul, "Geist" (Hegel), or ideas (Plato). In natural sciences energy, gravitation, information. Also intangible cultural heritage (folklore, customs, beliefs, traditions, knowledge, etc.).

title: identity
description: Those characteristics or conditions of a thing, person, or group that remain the same amid change or that distinguish a thing, person, or group from another.

title: water
description: A liquid made up of molecules of hydrogen and oxygen (HO2). When pure, it is colorless, tasteless, and odorless. It exists in gaseous, liquid, and solid forms; it is liquid at room temperature. It is the liquid of which seas, lakes, and rivers are composed, and which falls as rain. Water is one of the most plentiful and essential of compounds. It is vital to life, participating in virtually every process that occurs in plants and animals. One of its most important properties is its ability to dissolve many other substances. The versatility of water as a solvent is essential to living organisms. The term "water" is typically used to refer to the liquid form of this compound.

title: intermedial
description: Resulting from interdisciplinary activities between media.

title: light (energy)
description: That portion of the electromagnetic spectrum visible to the human eye, having a wavelength in the range from about 4,000 (violet) to about 7,700 (red) angstroms and may be perceived by the normal unaided human eye. It ranges from the red end to the violet end of the spectrum, with wavelengths from 700 to 400 nanometres and frequencies from 4.3 x 1014 to 7.5 x 1014 Hz. Like all electromagnetic radiation, light travels through empty space at a speed of about 186,000 miles per second (300,000 km/sec).

title: dance
description: Discipline involving the study of dancing and movement, including performance.

title: surveillance-capitalism
description: Concept in political economics which denotes the widespread collection and commodification of personal data by corporations.

title: artificial intelligence
description: Artificial intelligence is intelligence—perceiving, synthesizing, and inferring information—demonstrated by machines, as opposed to intelligence displayed by non-human animals and humans. Example tasks in which this is done include speech recognition, computer vision, translation between (natural) languages, as well as other mappings of inputs.

title: blockchain
description: Blocks of data created in a distributed ledger technology that was originally designed for cryptocurrency, but now being used in a wider range of implemenations.
alternative_titles: blockchains, blockchain technology, block chain, block chains, block chain technology

title: fulldome
description: Way to film and project movie or video material

title: food
description: Any material that can be digested or absorbed by the body of a human or other animal and used as a source of energy or some essential nutrient, to build and replace tissue, or to relieve hunger.

title: biocomputers
description: Systems of biologically derived molecules that perform computational processes.

title: storytelling
description: Telling or writing stories, especially recounting stories aloud to others, either from memory, ex tempore, or reading from notes or a book.
alternative_titles: story-telling, story telling, telling of stories, narration

title: artistic inventions
description: Unique or novel device, method, composition, idea or process either developed within the field art or for other fields through applying artistic means.

title: emergence
description: Phenomenon whereby larger entities arise through interactions among smaller/simpler entities such that the larger entities exhibit properties the smaller/simpler entities don't exhibit.

title: fiction
description: Genre that refers to works evoked from the imagination of the creator and not conferred as fact. In literature, fiction generally refers to the novel, novella, short story, and poetic forms.

title: images
description: Depictions and representations on a surface in two dimensions or low relief, or digital, whether the optical counterpart exists in reality or only in imagination. For example, the term may refer to a depiction as distinguished from its support, as when referring to a drawing as distinct from the paper upon which it is drawn.

title: 360° virtual walktrough
description: Simulation of an existing location, usually composed of a sequence of videos or still images. It may also use other multimedia elements (sound effects, music, narration, text).

title: taste
description: Sense by which the flavor or savor of things is perceived when they are brought into contact with the tongue.

title: light art
description: Form of visual art using light as a medium.
